comments.text:
Diamond was the best solid thermal conductor in existence before 
measurements of graphene showed that it was a bit better.
Thermal conductivity relies in the transfer of molecular  vibrations 
through the material.  Short, high strength bonds help those vibrations 
move.  There is a strong correlation between the speed of sound in a 
material and its thermal conductivity.
comments.author: Dan Heidel

comments.text:
Graphene is a crystal, you have to grow it and then shape it down/construct 
it into what you need, or you grow it into the the shape it needs to be 
immediately. It also isn't nearly as forgiving on Silicon crystal is, try 
to force it and you end up with useless Graphite, unless you were trying to 
make a pencil that is.

comments.text:
You can't force Graphene into anything, if you do it just becomes Graphite. 
Graphene is only graphene when it has a perfect atom arrangement, applying 
any physical force to it would ruin it.
comments.author: BIkaloss

comments.text:
+SciShow graphene as exciting as it sounds, has still some time to replace 
Si in semiconductor industry... what makes a semiconductor semiconductor is 
bandgap, and graphene has none! to open it, you have to use flouride 
(called chemical bandgap) or strain it (called mechanical bandgap)... both 
are really really tough! 
P.S: I know this as I am a scientist in a lab who is doing the later! :P

comments.text:
+Mike Duffy Wow, how have I not heard about this? If graphene can really be 
made that easily now, companies like Intel and AMD are no doubt racing to 
turn out graphene microprocessors as soon as possible. Silicon CPUs have 
been edging up on some heat-imposed limit for a while now, so progress 
there is not as fast as it used to be. Consumer CPUs have been hovering 
around 4 (maybe 5) GHz for a few years now. (That's most of the reason for 
the multicore boom.)

Edit: Looked up some stuff. Graphene transistors can theoretically run at 
over 400 GHz. It looks to be a good decade or two away, but we're making 
progress. (

comments.text:
The problem with single atom manipulation (i think thats what you're 
getting at when you say 3d printers) is they're really hard to scale, 
imagine it takes 2 minutes to build one molecule of a particular compound, 
and say just for the sake of argument that that molecule has a formula mass 
(or molar mass or molecular weight whatever term you learned in school they 
all basically mean the same thing) of 400 g/ mol
using some simple dimensional analysis ive calculated that producing one 
gram of this theoretical molecule would take 5,728,691,000,000,000 years, 
so its not really feasible.
thats what I think the really cool thing about chemistry is ... when you 
make a particular, youre making molecules build themselves, rather  forcing 
them together, idk thats just my personal philosophy of science 

if you want to check my work

1g*(1mol/400g)(6.02210^23 atoms/1mol)(2min/1atom)*(1year/525600min

comments.text:
It is not, due to the nature of tape method themselves.
It can only do work until it loses it's stickiness.
Another thing is that it becomes much harder to scale the graphene 
production as imperfect portions of graphene(where carbon atom forms 
pentagon instead of hexagon) will break off and leaving ripped sheets or 
much less durable low quality graphene sheet.
Worst thing is that as you use the tape, the tape catches micro debris and 
particles which furthers the imperfection in graphene, making them very low 
quality. (Please do not suggest clean room or vacuum room for graphene 
synthesis because the machinery involved would be so large that it has to 
be massive and massive clean room or vacuum room. Also making either of 
them would require so much money to build and maintain that which ever 
moronic company wants it can go swim in a pool full of mails from debt 
collectors.

Also your method of using conveyor belt... And tape... Yeah not gonna work.

What you are suggesting is slightly less impractical than using particle 
accelerator to convert energy into matter for industrial use, which is 
impossible due to energy consumption from the process and creating over a 
gram of anything in particle accelerator take ridiculous time.

Your solution seems obvious, but there is a reason why genius in south 
korea proposed copper/carbon sheet sandwich method using rollers and 
hydrocarbon coatings. Which can make large sheet of graphene. 

Another method involves silicon/germanium and hydrogen method which uses 
acid dipped germanium coated wafer and chemical vapor deposition method to 
create thin layer of graphene. It shows extremely little imperfection as 
well.

Also, no future has not been so underwhelming, it looks like it because 
morons around the world wants to make something that kills something more 
than anything and are putting relatively little funding to other 
researches. Moreover there has been many more discoveries but people does 
not look for them such as most people who have access to internet didn't 
know we found a boson particle in 2012 because no body cared to look into 
it.

top_comment.text: Why do you die? (like why does the heart stop beating when you grow old)﻿
top_comment.author: Hannah Han

comments.text:
thank you so much! its great to see people take the time to respond to a 
fellow stranger's question.
comments.author: Hannah Han

comments.text:
The answer is kind of complicated, and it's hard for me to explain easily 
without writing like 3 or 4 paragraphs. Basically, when you grow, your 
cells divide, and because your cells are dividing, DNA has to be replicated 
or copied. When the DNA is copied, mistakes can be made, and some genetic 
codes will be missing in each copy. Eventually, you might be missing the 
genetic code of making your skin smooth, causing wrinkles in the skin. 
After a while, some of the most important information will be lost, like 
how to even reproduce the cell. So, cells die, and your body can't create 
more to replace them, and then your body shuts down. First, you stop 
breathing, your heart stops beating. For the next 4-6, you are still able 
to be revived, but after those 4-6 minutes, your brain starts shutting down 
and you are dead. You can't be revived. The people that die at a really old 
age, like 85-100 something years old have these "fake" pieces of genetic 
code at the end of their DNA (like the plastic on your shoelaces) called 
telomeres, and when the genetic code is lost, the telomeres are lost 
instead of the important stuff, letting the person live longer. There is a 
substance called telomerase which lets us create more telomeres, making us 
"immortals", but the problem with telomerase is that there's a huge chance 
that it will cause diseases like cancer. So instead of dying of old age, we 
die of a disease. This is how I learned it, so other people might have a 
different answer. Sorry for the long answer, it's a pretty complicated 
subject.
comments.author: georgedodia

comments.text:
I think you meant to ask how we die and it's simple; our cells begin to age 
which means cell reproduction slows down, this explains why old people look 
old. Eventually this starts effecting the nervous, circulatory, and 
cardiovascular systems in your body which also explains why seniors aren't 
as flexible, fast, and tend to be more prone to diseases and memory loss. 
So if you are talking about death by age, it's most likely because your 
nervous system stops functioning.
comments.author: AsianSensation Studios

comments.author: Rich Boy

comments.text:
+Rich Boy The problem with making graphene armor is that you cannot have a 
perfect sheet of graphene on that scale (yet, maybe in the 5-10 years). 
Graphene grown today has grain boundaries which are weakest at that point. 
Think of 2 pieces of cloth stitched together. The weakest area is where 
they connect. Same problem with graphene. The graphene would just break at 
the boundaries. http://www.sciencemag.org/content/321/5887/385.short
comments.author: QuantumEngineer

comments.text:
+Rich Boy  Armor? Sure. Blade? Not sure. Creating a good edge that can last 
might be an issue given that the layers have limited interaction with one 
another.
comments.author: CyberizedFuture

comments.text:
+PacMonster0 You can only "see" graphene on 285 nm of SiO2, due to the 
optical interference between the substrate and the graphene. However, if 
you put a perfect piece of graphene on a table it would not be visible due 
to limited to no interference between the table and the graphene.
comments.author: QuantumEngineer

comments.text:
+CyberizedFuture Soooo... Graphene armors and blades can be a thing? If so,

+Andy Vander Weide
Not exactly. Graphite is misshaped and broken throughout. So the graphene 
in the graphite is broken into tiny pieces. So if you took large layers of 
graphene and stacked then yes you'd get graphite, but it would be a hell of 
lot stronger and more conductive then normal graphite. So it wouldn't be 
"just a sheet of pencil lead". It would basically be a sheet of armor 
plating.
comments.author: CyberizedFuture

comments.text:
graphene is visible.

http://ej.iop.org/images/1367-2630/12/11/113031/Full/nj361798fig2.jpg

And yes, technically 2 layers of graphene on top of each other is graphite. 
Graphene refers to just a single layer.

and i dont see why you cant stack graphene to make graphite ... but why

behind and make money off of last years semiconductor tech. There simply 
isn't enough time Intel spends on a certain Silicon fabrication size for 
other companies to come up with cheaper ways and enter the market.

Others are trying to enter the market since Intel's Silicon advantage is

production, they will either make bank upon selling it for the short time

technology to Intel.

comments.author: Shawn “NinjaYodeler” Butler

comments.text:
+WhoooLovesOrangeSoda People are still working on it because nothing goes 
from a lab to commercial viability quickly. The mechanisms and processes of 
introducing new materials into an industry take time and a lot of money. 
Patents need to be created and validated. Businesses need to be set up. 
People need to be trained. Also there might be unforeseen issues that take 
more time to find then initial positive results. For instance, there are 
numerous techniques for producing large quantities of graphene but most of 
those techniques tend to produce low quality graphene which would not work 
for most of the applications graphene would be useful for.

There's also the complications involved with once you have a reliable way 
to mass produce graphene in good quality how do you then incorporate it 
into existing technology. 

Also, your example is a red herring though. You could as just as well said 
that person is a reason why cancer should be completely cured next year. It 
doesn't apply to the topic and thus doesn't explain anything. Yes, smart 
people do amazing things given enough time and money.

know of on Earth) in our universe.

captions.text:
Graphene: everybody's talking about it. When
hearing some of its basic properties, you

might have wondered if people were confusing
it with some kind of substance only found

in comic books. It's one atom thick, conducts
electricity better than silver, conducts heat

better than diamond, and it's stronger than
steel. It would take the focused force of

an elephant balancing on a pencil point to
pierce through a piece of graphene as thick
as plastic wrap.

And yet, graphITE is made of the same stuff.
And yeah, that crumbly stuff used to make

your pencil is a lot less impressive. So what's
up? Graphene is made of carbon, and carbon

has only two naturally occurring crystalline
structures; graphite, which is just stacks

and stacks of graphene piled on top of each
other, and diamond, which is a network of

carbon atoms arranged into tetrahedrons one
after the other. For being composed of entirely

the same element, those two things don't seem
to have a lot in common. Diamond is clear,

graphite is black. Diamond is a nearly-perfect
electrical insulator, while graphite is both
a great conductor of heat and electricity.

The differences between these substances all
come down to the arrangement of their atoms.

Carbon has four outer electrons. In diamond,
all four of those electrons bond to carbon

atoms around it, forming those tetrahedrons.
This makes for an extremely rigid and strong

crystal. It's an insulator, because there
are no electrons left over to carry a current,

and it's clear because light can't easily
excite electrons that are tied up in such

stable bonds, which is where they'd otherwise
be absorbed. Graphite, on the other hand,

is a crystalline form of carbon in which each
atom is only bonded to three other carbon

atoms. Those atoms form a two-dimensional
sheet of hexagons in which each atom has one

unpaired electron left over. And those electrons
will go flying across the matrix of atoms

if you apply an electric current, allowing
it to readily conduct electricity. They also

gobble up any photons coming their way, which
is why graphite is black.

But while graphite is a great conductor, its
natural form consists of layers of those sheets.

So if a current is applied to it, those free
electrons have lots of different directions

they can go in, taking tangents up and down
and left and right and so on. But if you strip

away just a single layer, forming graphene,
then you have what amounts to an electron

super highway, a flat matrix of carbon atoms
for that current to fly across. And those

sheets of carbon are pretty easy to separate
because they're not molecularly bonded to

each other. That's why graphite is so soft.
Instead, they're held together by Van Der

Waal's bonds, kind of a weak, electrostatic
bond that's the same force that makes sticky

tape sticky. And in fact, graphene was only
discovered in 2004 when two physicists at

the University of Manchester, Andre Geim and
Konstantin Novoselov, decided to use sticky

tape to peel off thinner and thinner layers
from a slab of graphite. Eventually, they
got a layer just one atom thick.

So that's what it is, but what is it good
for? Because of its terrific conductive properties,

scientists are excited by the possibility
of using graphene as the replacement for silicon

in microchips. Not only can electrons move
faster across graphene, they're also subjected

to less noise. That means the electron can
move from one side of the sheet to the other

in a straight line without detouring around
a whole lot of atomic potholes. Scientists

think that graphene transistors could operate
at frequencies of up to a thousand gigahertz.
That's ten times the maximum of silicon.

Another proposed use of graphene is in touch
screens. The topmost layer of a touchscreen

has to be an excellent conductor of electricity,
so the device can sense your fingertip. The

material we use now is indium tin oxide, but
it's both rare and brittle. Even ground into

powder, graphene retains many of it's extraordinary
properties, so it could replace graphite or

other forms of carbon in anything from car
tires to double-A batteries to make them stronger
or more conductive.

The biggest problem with graphene though is
how hard it is to make. I mean, peeing off

a tiny sheet at a time with sticky tape isn't
really scaleable. We can grow graphene sheets

by hitting up a sheet of hydrocarbons like
methane until the hydrogen separates, leaving

only the carbon behind, but the graphene we
get from this is mostly low quality.

Basically, it's hard to create a one atom
thick sheet of anything. And it's also really

hard to get a completely pure sample of anything,
and here we're trying to do both. But then

again, the silicon industry faced the same
purity problem fifty years ago, and we eventually

solved that problem with time and some money.
So in some more time, and some more money,
I'm sure we'll do the same thing for graphene.

Thanks for watching this SciShow dose. If
you'd like to help us keep exploring the frontiers

of awesomeness, go to subbable.com/scishow
to find out how you can become a supporter.

And if you wanna keep getting smarter with
us, don't forget to go to youtube.com/scishow
and subscribe.

title: Graphene: The Next Big (But Thin) Thing
